attributes.comment:
I wish to comment on USCIS-2006-0044. My wife and I have adopted two children
from Russia in 2003 and we are in process of adopting a third right now. I have
specific comments regarding two fees which I have experienced as an adoptive
parent: (1) Petition to Classify Orphan as an Immediate Relative/Application for
Advance Processing of Orphan Petition (I-600/I-600A); and (2) Application for
Certification of Citizenship (N-600).

I-600/600A.
1. The costs for this are now $545 and are requested to increase to $670, an
increase of 23%. This is on top of a 352% increase over the past 13 years ($155
to $545). What has changed in processing orphan adoption requests that
requires a 23% increase in two years?
2. It appears that the stated ?determination? costs for I-600 are SIGNIFICANTLY
higher than for other applications with seemingly much higher Homeland Security
risk. I do not believe that adopting my 4 year old boy from Russia is in the same
class as other applications such as I-129/129F/130. Is USCIS doing too much
work in the wrong area?
3. Congress has authorized USCIS to recoup the costs of certain programs
(example: asylum) by charging extra on other immigration fees. I don?t have a
gripe with burdening immigrant adults with such fees, but asking adoptive US
citizen parents to bear such costs is distressing.

N-600
In it current form, I am VEHEMENTLY OPPOSED to any increase in this fee. It is
proposed to go from $255 to $460 (an 80% increase!). My wife and I have two
children adopted from Russia that automatically received citizenship in 2003 when
they entered the country. They subsequently (and automatically) received FREE
Green Cards (a very illogical step since they were not resident aliens, but
citizens). In November, 2006, I applied for and received US Passports for them
(very quickly, I might add). In December 2006 I paid $255 for each of my
children?s Certificates of Citizenship. I am projected to receive them in June
2007. USCIS?s justification for the increase is a large ?determination? cost. In our
case, there is no determination cost at all ? the information is already in USCIS
computers. All that is required is to print and mail the certificates.
After 2004, USCIS recognized the inequity and started issuing Certificates of
Citizenship to all new foreign adoptees automatically at no charge. But that
leaves a vast pool of Adoptive Parents who adopted before 2004, who are now
paying $255 and will soon have to pay $460 if they want Certificates of Citizenship
for their children. Until this inequity is corrected, I am very opposed to an
increase.

Finally I have a general comment. Adoptions cost increases are far exceeding the
inflation rate for a variety of reasons, but fee increases as discussed above are
part of the problem. My wife and I are upper middle class ? we ONLY had to take
a second mortgage on our home to adopt! For lower middle class or the poor,
adoption is becoming almost impossible. Even the IRS Adoption Tax Credit only
covers one third the cost of a foreign adoption (our current Russian adoption will
cost us $33,000). Even worse, some lower middle class and poor will be unable
to take advantage of the tax credit if their tax liability is low.
attributes.title: Comment Submitted by Mark Collins
